newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea to ease rules on foreign investment trusts.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea to ease rules on foreign investment trusts.

text.p: South Korea's finance ministry said on Wednesday it would ease rules on the entry of foreign investment trust companies into the local market as part of a drive to liberalise the financial sector.
It had earlier said qualified foreign investment trusts can open a branch or a joint venture with local firms from next month unless local market conditions are bad.
The ministry will no longer consider local conditions and will ease a requirement for experience in the business of at least 10 years when allowing foreign entries, a ministry statement said.
An individual foreign company can now have a 49 percent stake in a joint venture instead of the previous limit of 30 percent, the statement said.
But the 30 percent limit for an individual company would remain unchanged for a joint venture with one of South Korea's top 10 business conglomerates.

The rule that the combined foreign stake should not exceed 49 percent in a joint venture would also remain in force until December 1, 1998, when foreigners will be allowed to open a wholly-owned company.

The ministry will allow a foreign company with good business performance to set up a joint venture or a branch in South Korea even if it has less than 10 years of experience in the trust investment business, the statement said.
Parent companies' or affiliates' experience in the business would also be respected, it added.
